# S. 2 Additional simulation results 

In this section, we provide some additional simulation result. In Figure S. 2 we repeated the simulated experiment for simple hypotheses from Figure 1 but with $\alpha=0.01$ instead of $\alpha=0.05$. Obviously, the required sample size is larger for $\alpha=0.01$ than for $\alpha=0.05$. It can also be seen that the gain in percentage of sample size is smaller than for $\alpha=0.05$, however, due to the larger total sample size the absolute gain in sample size remains similar.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure S.2: Comparison of sample size and type I error between the SPRT and the boosted SPRT in a simple Gaussian testing setup for different signal strengths and $\alpha=0.01$. The boosted SPRT saves $2.3-8.4 \%$ of sample size compared to the SPRT and exhausts the significance level. The SPRT is becoming increasingly conservative for stronger signals.

In Figure S.3, we repeated the two-sided experiment from Figure 4 for $\alpha=0.01$. Again, the boosted SPRT saves a substantial number of samples compared to Wald's two-sided SPRT with approximated thresholds and nearly exhausts the type I and type II error. Interestingly, the percentage of saved samples approximately increases with $\beta$ for $\alpha=0.01$, while it decreases for $\alpha=0.05$.

![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Figure S.3: Comparison of sample size, type II and type I error probability between the Wald's approximated SPRT, Wald's conservative SPRT and the boosted SPRT in a simple Gaussian testing setup for different desired type II error probabilities $(\beta)$ and $\alpha=0.01$. Wald's conservative SPRT and our boosted method provably control the type I and type II error, while the SPRT with Wald's approximated thresholds does not. Furthermore, the boosted SPRT saves sample size and nearly exhausts the error probabilities.

# S. 3 Boosting with a stop for futility and discrete data 

In Section 5.1, we have shown that with discrete data and two-sided thresholds it might not be possible to find boosting factors such that the expected value of the boosted (super)martingale factors is exactly one. In this section, we propose a randomization approach that can be used to avoid conservative type I error control in these cases.

First, at each step $t$ choose the largest $b_{t}^{*} \geqslant 1$ among all $b_{t} \geqslant 1$ that ensures

$$
\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right] \leqslant 1
$$

Note that such a $b_{t}^{*}$ always exists, since $T_{\alpha}\left(x ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right)$ is left-continuous and nondecreasing in $x$. Then, in case of $b_{t}^{*} L_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}$, draw a random sample $U \sim[0,1]$ and reject $H_{0}$ if $U \leqslant \alpha a_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}$, where

$$
a_{t}=\frac{1-\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]}{\mathbb{P}_{0}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right)}
$$

Hence, even if our boosted process $\left(M_{t}^{\text {boost }}\right)$ crosses the lower threshold $\nu_{t}$, with this approach we still have a positive probability for rejection if $\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]$ is strictly smaller than one.

To see why this controls the type I error, we need the randomized Ville's inequality [17], a randomized improvement of Ville's inequality (7). It states that for any test supermartingale $\left(M_{t}\right)$

with respect to the filtration $\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right)$, we have that $\mathbb{P}_{0}\left(M_{r} \geqslant U / \alpha\right) \leqslant \alpha$ for all stopping times, where $U$ is uniform on $[0,1]$ and independent of $\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right)$. Now define

$$
\tilde{T}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right):=a_{t} \mathbb{1}\left\{b_{t}^{*} L_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}\right\}+T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right)
$$

Then $\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[\tilde{T}_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=1$. Now if we use $\tilde{T}_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right)$ instead of $T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right)$ as factor for our boosted test martingale, the test martingale has the same value if we did not stop for futility but it equals $a_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}$ (instead of 0 ) in case of $b_{t}^{*} L_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}$. Hence, due to randomized Ville's inequality [17], after stopping in case of $b_{t}^{*} L_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}$, we can reject the null hypothesis if $U \leqslant \alpha a_{t} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}$ while ensuring valid type I error control.

Example S. 1 (Continuation of Example 1). Suppose we have i.i.d. binary data $X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots$ with $\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[X_{t}\right]=1 / 3, \mathbb{E}_{1}\left[X_{t}\right]=2 / 3, \alpha=0.05, \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}=8$ and $\nu_{t}=7$. Then the largest $b_{t} \geqslant 1$ satisfying $\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t} L_{t} ; \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right] \leqslant 1$ is given by $b_{t}^{*}=7 / 4$. With this, we have $\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} ; \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=$ $5 / 6$ and $\mathbb{P}_{0}\left(b_{t}^{*} L_{t} \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right)=2 / 3$. Hence, $a_{t}=(1-5 / 6) /(2 / 3)=1 / 4$. Therefore, we can reject $H_{0}$ in case of $X_{t}=0$ if $U \leqslant \alpha a_{t} \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}=1 / 10$ (in case of $X_{t}=1$ we have $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }}=20$ and can reject anyway).

# S. 4 Implementation of the boosted two-sided SPRT 

In this section we provide some details on our implementation of the two-sided boosting method proposed in Theorem 5.3 that we, for example, used to generate Figure 4.

According to Proposition 5.4, one possibility would be to just replace the inequalities in (27) and (28) with equalities and then use a solver for nonlinear equation systems to find the optimal boosting factors. Appropriate solvers for this purpose are provided by the R packages nleqslv [8] and $B B$ [30]. While these work most of the time, we noticed that the algorithms sometimes fail to find a solution and then produce a warning, e.g. if our current boosted likelihood ratio value $\Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}$ is very close to $1 / \alpha$. For this reason, in our implementation we used a slightly different approach by formulating the following optimization problem with nonlinear constraints

$$
\max _{b_{t} \geqslant 1, b_{t}^{\text {inv }} \geqslant 1} b_{t}+b_{t}^{\text {inv }} \quad \text { s.t. (27) and (28) are satisfied. }
$$

We solved this using the NLOPT_LN_COBYLA algorithm from the nloptr [13] R package. While it produced the same results as the previously mentioned approaches in most cases, we found it to be more reliable in extreme scenarios (e.g. when our current boosted likelihood ratio value is very close to one of the thresholds). To avoid inflated error probabilities by all means, we verify every boosting factor by plugging it into (27) and (28). If one of the two expected values is greater than $1+10^{-7}$, we set both boosting factors to 1 . This ensures that we always have (sufficiently accurate) type I and type II error control, even if the optimization algorithm fails to provide valid solutions. In order to avoid conservatism by setting the boosting factors to one in those cases, one could also consider to apply the different algorithms one after the other if one fails to provide a sufficient solution. However, in our simulations we found the described proceeding to perform sufficiently well.

## S. 5 General forecaster-skeptic testing protocol
## S. 6 Comparison to Siegmund's SPRT

In this section, we compare our boosted SPRT to the SPRT with the approximated thresholds by Siegmund [27]. We consider a simple i.i.d. Gaussian testing setup $H_{0}: X_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ vs. $H_{1}: X_{t} \sim$ $\mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{1}, 1\right)$, where $\mu_{1}>0$ is the strength of the signal. Siegmund's approximations suggest to choose $\gamma_{1}=\frac{1-\beta}{\alpha \exp \left(\mu_{1} \rho\right)}$ and $\gamma_{0}=\frac{\beta \exp \left(\mu_{1} \rho\right)}{1-\alpha}$, where $\rho=0.583$. In Figure S.4, we compare the SPRT with these

```
Algorithm S. 1 SPRT in a general forecaster-skeptic testing protocol
    Input: Lower and upper SPRT thresholds \(\gamma_{0}\) and \(\gamma_{1}\).
    Output: Decision on the forecaster.
    \(\Lambda_{0}=1\)
    for \(t=1,2, \ldots\) do
        Reality announces \(Z_{t} \in \mathcal{Z}\)
        Forecaster announces a probability distribution \(\mathbb{P}_{0}^{t}\) on \(\mathcal{X}\)
        Skeptic announces a probability distribution \(\mathbb{P}_{1}^{t}\) on \(\mathcal{X}\)
        Reality announces \(X_{t} \in \mathcal{X}\)
        \(\Lambda_{t}=\Lambda_{t-1} \cdot \frac{p_{t}^{t}\left(X_{t}\right)}{p_{0}^{t}\left(X_{t}\right)}\)
        if \(\Lambda_{t} \geqslant \gamma_{1}\) then
            Stop and reject the forecaster
        end if
        if \(\Lambda_{t} \leqslant \gamma_{0}\) then
            Stop and accept the forecaster
        end if
    end for
```

approximated thresholds to our boosted SPRT in the power-one $(\beta=0)$ case and in Figure S. 5 for different desired type II errors $\beta$. In both cases $\alpha=0.05$ and the implementation of our boosted SPRT is exactly the same as in Figures 1 and 4.

It is easy to see that Siegmund's SPRT outperformed our boosted SPRT in all considered cases. While the difference in the power-one scenario is hardly visible, the gain in sample size for larger $\beta$ can be substantial. Note that the type II error in Figure S. 5 seems slightly inflated for Siegmund's SPRT, however, this should be negligible for practice. Hence, in this particular case Siegmund's SPRT may be preferred over our boosted SPRT. However, note that Siegmund's approximations are only asymptotically valid (for $\alpha \rightarrow 0$ and $\beta \rightarrow 0$ ) and hence it might be sensible to check their validity by such simulations before application, particularly if $\beta$ and/or $\alpha$ is large. Furthermore, the above thresholds, in particular the value of $\rho=0.583$, only work in the Gaussian example and require (nontrivial) adjustments for other distributions. In general, it is not possible at all to use Siegmund's approximations in settings with non-i.i.d. test statistics such as considered in Sections 3.2 and 4.2.

# S. 7 Proofs 

Proof of Theorem 2.1. We already noted that $\tau_{\text {trunc }}=\tau_{M}$ and $M_{t}^{\text {trunc }}=M_{t}$ for all $t<\tau_{M}$. Since $M_{t}^{\text {boost }} \geqslant M_{t}^{\text {trunc }}$ for all $t \in \mathbb{N}$, the first claim follows. Furthermore, since $\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right] \leqslant 1$ for all $t \in \mathbb{N}$, it immediately follows that $\left(M_{t}^{\text {boost }}\right)$ is a test supermartingale.

$$
\lim _{b \rightarrow b_{0}} \mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[\lim _{b \rightarrow b_{0}} T_{\alpha}\left(b L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{0} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]

Proof of Proposition 3.1. Due to the monotone likelihood ratio property (21), we know that

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\theta_{0}}\left(\lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) \geqslant x\right) \geqslant \mathbb{P}_{\theta}\left(\lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) \geqslant x\right) \quad\left(\theta \leqslant \theta_{0}, x \geqslant 0\right)
$$

where $\theta_{t} \geqslant \theta_{0}$. This implies that

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\theta_{0}}\left(T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t} \lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) ; M\right) \geqslant x\right) \geqslant \mathbb{P}_{\theta}\left(T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t} \lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) ; M\right) \geqslant x\right) \quad\left(\theta \leqslant \theta_{0}, x \geqslant 0\right)
$$

for any $\alpha \in(0,1), M>0$ and $b_{t} \geqslant 1$. Hence, if $\mathbb{E}_{\theta_{0}}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t} \lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) ; M\right) \mid \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}\right] \leqslant 1$, we also have $\mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{t} \lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) ; M\right) \mid \Lambda_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}\right] \leqslant 1$ for all $\theta<\theta_{0}$.

Proof of Theorem 5.1. First, note that $M_{t}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}$ implies that $\prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime}} b_{i} L_{i} \leqslant \nu_{t}^{M} \prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime}} b_{i}$ for some $t^{\prime} \leqslant t$, and hence $M_{t^{\prime}} \leqslant \nu_{t^{\prime}}^{M}$. Therefore, if $t<\tau_{M}$, the boosted martingale has not stopped for futility yet, which shows that $M_{t}^{\text {boost }} \geqslant M_{t}$ for all $t<\tau_{M}$ and $\delta_{\text {boost }} \geqslant \delta$ in the same manner as in Theorem 2.1. We now show that $M_{t} \leqslant \nu_{t}^{M}$ implies that $\tau_{\text {boost }} \leqslant t$. If $\nu_{t}=\nu_{t}^{M} \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i}$, then $M_{t} \leqslant \nu_{t}^{M}$ is equivalent to $M_{t} \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i} \leqslant \nu_{t}^{M} \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i}=\nu_{t}$. If $\nu_{t}=1 / \alpha$, then $\tau_{\text {boost }} \leqslant t$, since we either have $M_{t}^{\text {boost }}=0$ or $M_{t}^{\text {boost }}=1 / \alpha$. Obviously, $M_{t} \geqslant 1 / \alpha$ implies that $\tau_{\text {boost }} \leqslant t$, which shows that $\tau_{\text {boost }} \leqslant \tau_{M}$. Finally, (25) immediately implies that $\left(M_{t}^{\text {boost }}\right)$ is a test supermartingale.

Proof of Proposition 5.2. We only show that $b \mapsto \mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]$ is a continuous mapping. The remaining proof follows in the exact same manner as in Proposition 2.2. Let $b_{1} \geqslant 1$ and $\epsilon>0$. We want to show that for $b_{2}>b_{1}$ sufficiently close to $b_{1}$ we have that

$$
\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{2} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{1} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right] \leqslant \epsilon
$$

For this, we first note that

$$
\min \left(b_{2} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right]\right)-\min \left(b_{1} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right] \leqslant \epsilon / 2 \text { for all } x \geqslant 0\right.
$$

for $b_{2}$ sufficiently close to $b_{1}$. Let $f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}$ be the density of $L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ under $\mathbb{P}_{0}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{2} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{0}\left[T_{\alpha}\left(b_{1} L_{t} ; M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}, \nu_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right] \\
& =\int_{\substack{\frac{\alpha}{b_{2} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}}}}^{\infty} \min \left(b_{2} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right]\right) f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}(x) d x-\int_{\substack{\frac{\alpha}{b_{1} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}}}}^{\infty} \min \left(b_{1} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right]\right) f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}(x) d x \\
& \leqslant \int_{\substack{\frac{\alpha}{b_{2} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}}}}^{\infty} \min \left(b_{2} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right]\right) f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}(x) d x-\int_{\substack{\frac{\alpha}{b_{1} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}}}}^{\infty} \min \left(b_{2} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right]\right) f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}(x) d x+\epsilon / 2 \\
& =\int_{\substack{\frac{\alpha}{b_{2} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}}}}^{\infty} \min \left(b_{2} x, 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right]\right) f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}(x) d x+\epsilon / 2 \\
& \leqslant 1 /\left[M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }} \alpha\right] \int_{\substack{\frac{\alpha}{b_{2} M_{t-1}^{\text {boost }}}}}^{\infty} f_{L_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}}(x) d x+\epsilon / 2 \\
& \leqslant \epsilon,
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality holds for $b_{2}$ sufficiently close to $b_{1}$.
Proof of Theorem 5.3. Ville's inequality implies that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbb{P}_{0}\left(\exists t \in \mathbb{N}: \Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }} \geqslant 1 / \alpha\right) \leqslant \alpha \\
\mathbb{P}_{1}\left(\exists t \in \mathbb{N}: \Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost,inv }} \geqslant 1 / \beta\right) \leqslant \beta
\end{gathered}
$$

(S.3) immediately implies the type I error control of $\delta^{\text {boost }}$. To deduce type II error control of $\delta^{\text {boost }}$ from (S.4), it remains to show that $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}, t \in \mathbb{N}$, implies $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost,inv }} \geqslant 1 / \beta$ for some $t^{\prime} \in \mathbb{N}$. To see

this, just note that $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}$ implies that there is a $t^{\prime} \leqslant t$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime}} b_{i} \lambda_{i}\left(X_{i}\right) \leqslant \beta \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i} \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i}^{\mathrm{inv}} \wedge \prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime \prime}} b_{i} \lambda_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)<1 / \alpha \forall t^{\prime \prime}<t^{\prime} \\
\Leftrightarrow & \prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime}} \frac{b_{i}^{\mathrm{inv}}}{\lambda_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)} \geqslant \frac{1}{\beta} \wedge \alpha \prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime \prime}} b_{i} \prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime \prime}} b_{i}^{\mathrm{inv}}<\prod_{i=1}^{t^{\prime \prime}} \frac{b_{i}^{\mathrm{inv}}}{\lambda_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)} \forall t^{\prime \prime}<t^{\prime} \\
\Longrightarrow & \Lambda_{t^{\prime}}^{\text {boost,inv }} \geqslant 1 / \beta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Proposition 5.4. Since the expected values in (27) and (28) are continuous functions of the boosting factors if $\lambda_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)$ is continuously distributed (see proof of Proposition 5.2 for more insights), the claim follows immediately by the Poincaré-Miranda theorem [16].

Proof of Proposition 5.5. Since $b_{t} \geqslant 1$ for all $t \in \mathbb{N}$, we immediately have that $\Lambda_{t} \geqslant 1 / \alpha$ implies $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }} \geqslant 1 / \alpha$. Now suppose $\Lambda_{t} \leqslant \beta$ for some $t$. Let's first consider the case $\nu_{t}=\beta \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i} \prod_{i=1}^{t} b_{i}^{\text {inv }}$. Since $b_{i}^{\text {inv }} \geqslant 1$ for all $i \leqslant t, \Lambda_{t} \leqslant \beta$ immediately implies $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }} \leqslant \nu_{t}$. Now consider the case $\nu_{t}=1 / \alpha$. Then $\tau_{\text {boost }} \leqslant t$, since we either have $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }}=0$ or $\Lambda_{t}^{\text {boost }}=1 / \alpha$.

abstract:
Wald's sequential probability ratio test (SPRT) is a cornerstone of
sequential analysis. Based on desired type-I, II error levels $\alpha, \beta$,
it stops when the likelihood ratio crosses certain thresholds, guaranteeing
optimality of the expected sample size. However, these thresholds are not
closed form and the test is often applied with approximate thresholds
$(1-\beta)/\alpha$ and $\beta/(1-\alpha)$ (approximate SPRT). When $\beta > 0$,
this neither guarantees error control at $\alpha,\beta$ nor optimality. When
$\beta=0$ (power-one SPRT), this method is conservative and not optimal. The
looseness in both cases is caused by overshoot: the test statistic overshoots
the thresholds at the stopping time. Numerically calculating thresholds may be
infeasible, and most software packages do not do this. We improve the
approximate SPRT by modifying the test statistic to avoid overshoot. Our
`sequential boosting' technique uniformly improves power-one SPRTs $(\beta=0)$
for simple nulls and alternatives, or for one-sided nulls and alternatives in
exponential families. When $\beta > 0$, our techniques provide guaranteed error
control at $\alpha,\beta$, while needing less samples than the approximate SPRT
in our simulations. We also provide several nontrivial extensions: confidence
sequences, sampling without replacement and conformal martingales.
